title: 113_hr3781
content: The "American Unemployed Worker Investment Act of 2013" provides a credit for employers who hire individuals receiving unemployment compensation. The "American Unemployed Worker Investment Act of 2013" offers a credit for employers hiring individuals on unemployment compensation. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code defines a qualified unemployment compensation recipient for small business employers. The term 'qualified unemployment compensation recipient' refers to an individual certified by a local agency as not a student for at least 6 months prior to the hiring date, receiving unemployment compensation, and hired within 2 years of the enactment. The text discusses the eligibility criteria for the employer tax credit, specifying that it applies to employers with 10-25 full-time equivalent employees. It also mentions a maximum credit of $4,000 per employee and the requirement of full-time employment for one year to qualify for the credit. The text introduces a new requirement for qualified unemployment compensation recipients to be eligible for the employer tax credit. It mandates full-time employment for at least 35 hours per week for one year and an increase in the employer's full-time equivalent employees by 1 for at least 1 year. The tax credit eligibility for qualified individuals is amended to require full-time employment for at least 1 year and an increase in full-time equivalent employees by 1 year. The tax credit eligibility for qualified individuals is amended to include qualified veterans and unemployment compensation recipients. The amendments apply to individuals starting work for the employer after the enactment of the Act.
